St. Helens, 27 July, 1858.

I was much pleased with your last letter, you told me so much of all the little ones, & you have a supply of sausages! We also killed a pig, but made no sausages, but I am enjoying rye bread, how that reminds me of Germany. Georgie calls it Kuku, it agrees well with the little one, a little now & then. Portus rode this morning to Portland & will return to morrow night, I hope he will remain a long time with us. He seems to like to be here to.

George is well, dayly out to keep the Cattle together. Much rain has fallen & water standing everywhere, the Blacks bring us numbers of little fish & we have them fried for breakfast. — We had an invitation to a ball at Belfast, but could of course not go. I feel much better & have a good appetit.

Edward thinks Morten Bay a good Climat for me. I fear it is to warm, last summer I suffered much from the heat even here; this climat would be good enough if the house had not been so stupidly built in a low place. — Georgie has at last 6 teeth & is broad & fat. Curls all over his head, he chatters now all day long, you are "Tatti Caha" & Berti and Edy are always in his mouth, for instance "Berti, Edy hungrig", if I ask what shall we give them: "Kuku, Poddi, Bo, & Berti bed or Edy bath. "Port a b t" that means Port reading, then he shakes hand & says "How do", if any one offers a dirty hand he draws his hand back & says fi fie. He likes the book of Cock Robin & I must read it to him, he calls it "I kill Ko". — George says he is a model child! But now enough. with love etc. [...]
